notes: The subject of the story. This one is easy.

notes: The author of the story. This one is easy.

biography.legge: German missionary in China and civil servant in Hong Kong.

reference.text: When Dr. Eitel’s ‘Handbook for the Student of Chinese Buddhism’ appeared in 1870, the difficulty occasioned by the Sanskrit words and names was removed, but the other difficulty remained; and I was not able to look into the book again for several years.

biography.legge: British scholar of Sanskrit.

reference.text: In the meantime I kept studying the subject of Buddhism from various sources; and in 1878 began to lecture, here in Oxford, on the Travels with my Davis Chinese scholar, who was at the same time Boden Sanskrit scholar.

biography.legge: Japanese Buddhist priest.

reference.text: The want of a good and clear text had been supplied by my friend, Mr. Bunyiu Nanjio, who sent to me from Japan a copy, the text of which is appended to the translation and notes, and of the nature of which some account is given in the Introduction (page 4), and towards the end of this Preface.

biography.legge: French sinologist.

reference.text: While preparing my own version I made frequent reference to previous translations:—those of M. Abel Rémusat, ‘Revu, complété, et augmenté d’éclaircissements nouveaux par MM. Klaproth et Landresse’ (Paris, 1836); of the Rev. Samuel Beal (London, 1869), and his revision of it, prefixed to his ‘Buddhist Records of the Western World’ (Trübner’s Oriental Series, 1884); and of Mr. Herbert A. Giles, of H.M.’s Consular Service in China (1877).

reference.text: To these I have to add a series of articles on ‘Fa-hsien and his English Translators,’ by Mr. T. Watters, British Consul at Î-Chang (China Review, 1879, 1880).

biography.legge: Anglo-Scottish Protestant missionary.

reference.text: In transliterating the names of Chinese characters I have generally followed the spelling of Morrison rather than the Pekinese, which is now in vogue.

biography.legge: British Methodist missionary in Sri Lanka.

links.text: "Biographical Dictionary of Christian Missions" edited by Gerald H. Anderson
Online Books by R. Spence Hardy

reference.text: My principal help has been the full and masterly handbook of Eitel, mentioned already, and often referred to as E. H. Spence Hardy’s ‘Eastern Monachism’ (E. M.) and ‘Manual of Buddhism’ (M. B.) have been constantly in hand, as well as Rhys Davids’ Buddhism, published by the Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge, his Hibbert Lectures, and his Buddhist Suttas in the Sacred Books of the East, and other writings.

biography.legge: Founder of the Pali Text Society.

biography.legge: German scholar of Indology.

reference.text: Dr. Hermann Oldenberg, certainly a great authority on Buddhistic subjects, says that ‘a biography of Buddha has not come down to us from ancient times, from the age of the Pâli texts; and, we can safely say, no such biography existed then’ (‘Buddha—His Life, His Doctrine, His Order,’ as translated by Hoey, p. 78).

biography.legge: The Buddha.

biography.legge: Oriental Reader at the Clarendon Press.

links.text: "The Oxford University Press: An Informal History" by Peter H. Sutcliffe

reference.text: That we have succeeded so well as we have done is owing chiefly to the intelligence, ingenuity, and untiring attention of Mr. J. C. Pembrey, the Oriental Reader.

biography.legge: English Anglican reverend and missionary in China for  the Church Missionary Society.

"The Life and Times of The Reverend James Henry Sedgwick and his wife Ellen Jennings Parents of Harold Sedgwick, alias Claude Harold Annesley A Narrative, and Compilation of the Facts of his life." by Kristine M. Herron

reference.text: I am indebted for the use of it to the Rev. J. H. Sedgwick, University Chinese Scholar.

title.legge: Major General, Companion of the Order of the Star of India, Knight Commander of the Order of the Indian Empire

biography.legge: British army engineer and founder of the Archaeological Survey of India.

reference.text: There is no difficulty in laying it down after he crossed the Indus from the east to west into the Punjâb, all the principal places, at which he touched or rested, having been determined by Cunningham and other Indian geographers and archaeologists.

title.legge: Fellow of the Royal Society, Fellow of the Geological Society of London

biography.legge: English geologist.

reference.text: A doubt in intimated on page 24 as to the identification of T’o-leih with Darada, but Greenough’s ‘Physical and Geological Sketch-Map of British India’ shows ‘Dardu Proper,’ all lying on the east of the Indus, exactly in the position where the Narrative would leas us to place it.

biography.legge: Third emperor of the Ming Dynasty.

reference.text: I have read the accounts of him in the ‘Memoirs of Eminent Monks,’ compiled in A.D. 519, and a later work, the ‘Memoirs of Marvellous Monks,’ by the third emperor of the Ming dynasty (A.D. 1403-1424), which, however, is nearly all borrowed from the other; and all in them that has an appearance of verisimilitude can be brought within brief compass.

biography.legge: Indian Mahayana meditation and Vinaya master.

reference.text: It is said in the end that after his return to China, he went to the capital (evidently Nanking), and there, along with the Indian Śramaṇa Buddha-bhadra, executed translations of some of the works which he had obtained in India; and that before he had done all that he wished to do in this way, he removed to King-chow (in the present Hoo-pih), and died in the monastery of Sin, at the age of eighty-eight, to the great sorrow of all who knew him.

biography.legge: Chinese geographer during the Northern Wei Dynasty.

reference.text: The Catalogue Raisonné of the imperial library of the present dynasty (chap. 71) mentions two quotations from it by Le Tâo-yüen, a geographical writer of the dynasty of the Northern Wei (A.D. 386-584), one of them containing 89 characters, and the other 276; both of them given as from the ‘Narrative of Fâ-hien.’

biography.legge: French philosopher, journalist, and statesman.

reference.text: ii. In his article on M. J. Barthélemy Saint Hilaire’s ‘Le Bouddha et sa Religion,’ republished in his ‘Chips from a German Workshop,’ vol. i. (1868), Professor Max Müller (p. 215) says, ‘The young prince became the founder of a religion which, after more than two thousand years, is still professed by 455 millions of human beings,’ and he appends the following note: ‘Though truth is not settled by majorities, it would be interesting to know which religion counts at the present moment the largest numbers of believers. Berghaus, in his “Physical Atlas,” gives the following division of the human race according to religion:—“Buddhists 31.2 per cent, Christians 30.7, Mohammedans 15.7, Brahmanists 13.4, Heathens 8.7, and Jews 0.3.” As Berghaus does not distinguish the Buddhists in China from the followers of Confucius and Laotse, the first place on the scale belongs really to Christianity. It is difficult in China to say to what religion a man belongs, as the same person may profess two or three. The emperor himself, after sacrificing according to the ritual of Confucius, visits a Tao-ssé temple, and afterwards bows before an image of Fo in a Buddhist chapel. (“Mélanges Asiatiques de St. Pétersbourg,” vol. ii. p. 374.)’

biography.legge: German philologist and Orientalist.

biography.legge: Chinese diplomat and statesman during the Qing Dynasty.

reference.text: At an interview with the former Chinese ambassador, Kwo Sung-tâo, in Paris, in 1878, I begged him to write out for me the amount, with the authority for it, and he assured me that it could not be done.

biography.legge: Third emperor of the Qing Dynasty.

reference.text: Among ‘the strange principles’ which the emperor of the K’ang-hsî period, in one of his famous Sixteen Precepts, exhorted his people to ‘discountenance and put away, in order to exalt the correct doctrine,’ Buddhism and Tâoism were both included.

biography.legge: Second emperor of the After Ts’in Dynasty.
biography.modern: Second emperor of the Later Qin Dynasty.

reference.text: He adopted Hwăng-che for the style of his reign in 399, and the cyclical name of that year was Kăng-tsze.

biography.legge: Monk who joined Fâ-hien on his travels.
biography.modern: Monk who joined Fǎxiǎn on his travels.

text.legge: Deploring the mutilated and imperfect state of the collection of the Books of Discipline, in the second year of the period Hwăng-che, being the Ke-hâe year of the cycle, he entered into an engagement with Hwuy-king, Tâo-ching, Hwuy-ying, and Hwuy-wei, that they should go to India and seek for the Disciplinary Rules.
text.modern: Deploring the mutilated and imperfect state of the collection of the Books of Discipline, in the second year of the period Hóng shǐ, being the Ke-hâe year of the cycle, he entered into an engagement with Huìjǐng, Tâo-ching, Hwuy-ying, and Hwuy-wei, that they should go to India and seek for the Disciplinary Rules.

biography.legge: Second king of the Western Ts’in dynasty.
biography.modern: Second king of the Western Qin dynasty.

text.legge: After starting from Ch’ang-gan, they passed through Lung, and came to the kingdom of K’een-kwei, where they stopped for the summer retreat.
text.modern: After starting from Cháng'ān, they passed through Lǒng, and came to the kingdom of Gānguī, where they stopped for the summer retreat.

biography.legge: First king of the Western Ts’in dynasty.
biography.modern: First king of the Western Qin dynasty.

reference.text: The first king was Kwo-jin, and received his appointment from the sovereign of the chief Ts’in kingdom in 385.

biography.legge: Third king of the Southern Leang.
biography.modern: Third king of the Southern Liáng.

text.legge: When that was over, they went forward to the kingdom of Now-t’an, crossed the mountain of Yang-low, and reached the emporium of Chang-yih.
text.modern: When that was over, they went forward to the kingdom of Rùtán, crossed the mountain of Yǎnglóu, and reached the emporium of Zhāngyè.

biography.legge: First king of the Southern Leang.
biography.modern: First king of the Southern Liáng.

reference.text: The ‘southern Leang’ arose in 397 under a T’ŭh-făh Wû-kû, who was succeeded in 399 by a brother, Le-luh-koo; and he again by his brother, the Now-t’an of the text, in 402, who was not yet king therefore when Fâ-hien and his friends reached his capital.

biography.legge: Second king of the Southern Leang.
biography.modern: Second king of the Southern Liáng.

reference.text: The ‘southern Leang’ arose in 397 under a T’ŭh-făh Wû-kû, who was succeeded in 399 by a brother, Le-luh-koo; and he again by his brother, the Now-t’an of the text, in 402, who was not yet king therefore when Fâ-hien and his friends reached his capital.

biography.legge: King of the Northern Leang.
biography.modern: King of the Northern Liáng.

reference.text: Its king at this time was, probably, Twan-yeh of ‘the northern Leang.’

biography.legge: Monk who joined Fâ-hien on his travels.
biography.modern: Monk who joined Fǎxiǎn on his travels.

reference.text: Here they met with Che-yen, Hwuy-keen, Săng-shâo, Pâo-yun, and Săng-king; and in pleasant association with them, as bound on the same journey with themselves, they passed the summer retreat (of that year) together, resuming after it their travelling, and going on to T’un-hwang, (the chief town) in the frontier territory of defence extending for about 80 le from east to west, and about 40 from north to south.

biography.legge: Monk who joined Fâ-hien on his travels.

biography.legge: Envoy from T’un-hwang.
biography.modern: Envoy from Dūnhuáng.

reference.text: Their company, increased as it had been, halted there for some days more than a month, after which Fâ-hien and his four friends started first in the suite of an envoy, having separated (for a time) from Pâo-yun and his associates.

biography.legge: Prefect of T'un-hwang.
biography.modern: Prefect of Dūnhuáng.

reference.text: Le Hâo, the prefect of T’un-hwang, had supplied them with the means of crossing the desert (before them), in which there are many evil demons and hot winds.

biography.legge: British missionary in China.

reference.text: In his ‘Vocabulary of Proper Names,’ p. 23, Dr. Porter Smith says:—‘It extends from the eastern frontier of Mongolia, south-westward to the further frontier of Turkestan, to within six miles of Ilchî, the chief town of Khoten.

biography.legge: British missionary in China.

reference.text: The clothes of the common people are coarse, and like those worn in our land of Han, some wearing felt and others coarse serge or cloth of hair;—this was the only difference seen among them.

biography.legge: King of Shen-shen.
biography.modern: King of Shànshàn.

reference.text: The king professed (our) Law, and there might be in the country more than four thousand monks, who were all students of the hînayâna.

biography.legge: Maître d’hôtellerie of Woo-e Monastery.
biography.modern: Maître d’hôtellerie of Wūyí Monastery.

reference.text: Fâ-hien, through the management of Foo Kung-sun, maître d’hôtellerie, was able to remain (with his company in the monastery where they were received) for more than two months, and here they were rejoined by Pâo-yun and his friends.

biography.legge: Governor of Khoten.
biography.modern: Governor of Khotan.

links.text: "Ruins of Desert Cathay: Personal Narrative of Explorations in Central Asia and Westernmost China Vol. II" by M. Aurel Stein

reference.text: Dr. P. Smith gives (p. 11) the following description of it:—‘A large district on the south-west of the desert of Gobi, embracing all the country south of Oksu and Yarkand, along the northern base of the Kwun-lun mountains, for more than 300 miles from east to west. The town of the same name, now called Ilchî, is in an extensive plain on the Khoten river, in lat. 37° N., and lon. 80° 35' E. After the Tungâni insurrection against Chinese rule in 1862, the Mufti Hâji Habeeboolla was made governor of Khoten, and held the office till he was murdered by Yakoob Beg, who became for a time the conqueror of all Chinese Turkestan. Khoten produces fine linen and cotton stuffs, jade ornaments, copper, grain, and fruits.’

biography.legge: Leader of the Dungan Revolt and the Yettishar state.

reference.text: Dr. P. Smith gives (p. 11) the following description of it:—‘A large district on the south-west of the desert of Gobi, embracing all the country south of Oksu and Yarkand, along the northern base of the Kwun-lun mountains, for more than 300 miles from east to west. The town of the same name, now called Ilchî, is in an extensive plain on the Khoten river, in lat. 37° N., and lon. 80° 35' E. After the Tungâni insurrection against Chinese rule in 1862, the Mufti Hâji Habeeboolla was made governor of Khoten, and held the office till he was murdered by Yakoob Beg, who became for a time the conqueror of all Chinese Turkestan. Khoten produces fine linen and cotton stuffs, jade ornaments, copper, grain, and fruits.’

biography.legge: Chinese monk who wrote about his travels.

reference.text: YU-TEEN is a pleasant and prosperous kingdom, with a numerous and flourishing population.

notes: Xuánzàng is even more well known than Fǎxiǎn.

biography.legge: King of Yu-teen.
biography.modern: King of Yú Tián.

reference.text: The lord of the country lodged Fâ-hien and the others comfortably, and supplied their wants, in a monastery called Gomati, of the mahâyâna school.

biography.legge: Possibly an alias for another of Fâ-hien's companions.
biography.modern: Possibly an alias for another of Fǎxiǎn's companions.

reference.text: Hwuy-king, Tâo-ching, and Hwuy-tah set out in advance towards the country of K’eeh-ch’â; but Fâ-hien and the others, wishing to see the procession of images, remained behind for three months.

biography.legge: Queen of Yu-teen.
biography.modern: Queen of Yú Tián.

reference.text: Over the city gate they pitch a large tent, grandly adorned in all possible ways, in which the king and queen, with their ladies brilliantly arrayed, take up their residence (for the time).

biography.legge: American linguist, missionary, and Sinologist.

reference.text: Giles and Williams call this ‘the oratory of Buddha.’

biography.legge: Tartar who went with Săng-shâo to Kophene.
biography.modern: Tartar who went with Sēng Shào to Kophene.

reference.text: WHEN the processions of images in the fourth month were over, Săng-shâo, by himself alone, followed a Tartar who was an earnest follower of the Law, and proceeded towards Kophene.

biography.legge: King of Tsze-hoh.
biography.modern: King of Qí Guó.

reference.text: Its king was a strenuous follower of our Law, and had (around him) more than a thousand monks, mostly students of the mahâyâna.

biography.legge: King of K’eeh-ch’â.
biography.modern: King of Jié Chā.

reference.text: IT happened that the king of the country was then holding the pañcha parishad, that is, in Chinese, the great quinquennial assembly.

biography.legge: Reigning from 268 BCE to 232 BCE Aśoka was the emperor of the Mauyuran Empire which spanned nearly the entire Indian subcontinent.

reference.text: When this is to be held, the king requests the presence of the Śramans from all quarters (of his kingdom).

biography.legge: Chinese envoy during Emperor Wu of Han's reign.

reference.text: Giles thinks the fruit here was the guava, because the ordinary name for ‘pomegranate’ is preceded by gan (安); but the pomegranate was called at first Gan Shih-lâu, as having been introduced into China from Gan-seih by Chang K’een, who is referred to in chapter vii.

biography.legge: Propheseied Buddha who will revive the Dhamma after the end of the current dispensation.

reference.text: In this kingdom there was formerly an Arhan, who by his supernatural power took a clever artificer up to the Tushita heaven, to see the height, complexion, and appearance of Maitreya Bodhisattva, and then return and make an image of him in wood.

title.legge: Fellow of the Royal Geographical Society

biography.legge: British vice-consul in China.

reference.text: Through him, by B.C. 115, a regular intercourse was established between China and the thirty-six kingdoms or states of that quarter;—see Mayers’ Chinese Reader’s Manual, p. 5.

biography: Chinese diplomat sent to Rome in 97 AD.

reference.text: The (place and arrangements) are to be found in the Records of the Nine Interpreters, but neither Chang K’een nor Kan Ying had reached the spot.

title.legge: 1st Baronet, Fellow of the Royal Society

biography: Member of the United Kingdom Parliament and Colonial Secretary in Ceylon.

reference.text: He quotes the words of Sir Emerson Tennent, that it is ‘the oldest historical tree in the world;’ but this must be denied if it be true, as Eitel says, that the tree at Buddha Gayâ, from which the slip that grew to be this tree was taken more than 2000 years ago, is itself still living in its place.

biography.legge: Prefect of Ch’ang-kwang.
biography.modern: Prefect of Chǎngguǎng.

reference.text: The prefect Le E was a reverent believer in the Law of Buddha.
